bibl.title: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, February 21, 1900

div1.p: Lazear describes his domestic arrangements and gives his opinion on the Cuban political situation.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, February 21, 1900
div1.opener:
DR. JESSE W. LAZEAR,
835 PARK AVE.
Columbia Barracks
Havana Cuba
Feb 21 1900
OFFICE HOURS,
4.30-6 P. M.
Baltimore.
My dear Mother,-
div1.p:
I was glad to get your
letter this morning. It does not matter
about the medicines. Most of them
were half-filled bottles. I should not
have left them out, but I was in
such a hurry at the last I was never
so rushed before in my life.

We are getting things in shape here
Mabel has made a very pretty
partition dividing our two larger house
into two rooms. She made it out
of matting rugs sewed together. The
matting we obtained from a Chinese
store in Havana and is the
same material that is used as
a covering for tea boxes. It makes
a very nice appearance.

Since I wrote before we have had
a rain and a cool spell known here
as a Norther. There was a high
wind and heavy army blankets were
very comfortable.

Thank you very much for the “Sun”
They come promptly and I enjoy them very
much. There is no good paper in
DR. JESSE W. LAZEAR,
835 PARK AVE.
OFFICE HOURS,
4.30-6 P. M.
BALTIMORE.
Havana so I wait for the “Sun” and
enjoy the news three days old as
much as thought it were fresh.

My work is going on nicely
and promises to be very satisfactory.

The outlook from the camp here is very
beautiful. There is the sea on one
side and on the other the town of
Quemados about half a mile off
with a large palace now occupied
by General Lee as headquarters of the division
of Havana and Pinar del Rio.

The political problem here is more
complicated than I had supposed
The Cubans do not amount to much
The best element here is the Spanish
The Cubans do not want annexation
but I don't think the U.S. would dare
to give them independence as trouble
would be sure to result.

It is said that the Cubans who have
been placed in power are just as
corrupt as the Spaniards ea were.
The problem is interesting.

div1.opener:
DR. JESSE W. LAZEAR,
835 PARK AVE.
OFFICE HOURS,
4.30-6 P. M.
BALTIMORE.
div1.p:
You need put only a two cent stamp
on letters to Cuba. Letters from Cuba
to the states require five cents,
except those of soldiers.
